natural problem: Compute $121_3+2122_3-1200_3-2111_3$. Express your answer in base 3.
natural solution: It doesn't matter the order in which we add and subtract values, but we'll start with $2122_3-2111_3$ since the values are close. $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 2& 1 & 2 & 2_3\\ &- & 2 & 1 & 1 & 1_3\\ \cline{2-6} & & & & 1 & 1_3\\ \end{array} $$Now we're left with  $121_3-1200_3+11_3$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 121"
and h1 : "b = 2122"
and h2 : "c = 1200"
and h3 : "d = 2111"
shows  "a + b - c - d = -221"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $121_3+2122_3-1200_3-2111_3$. Express your answer in base 3. The final Answer is -221_3
 ### Proof
 It doesn't matter the order in which we add and subtract values, but we'll start with $2122_3-2111_3$ since the values are close. $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 2& 1 & 2 & 2_3\\ &- & 2 & 1 & 1 & 1_3\\ \cline{2-6} & & & & 1 & 1_3\\ \end{array} $$Now we're left with  $121_3-1200_3+11_3$.
 We add $121_3+11_3$. $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & & 1 & 2 & 1_3\\ &+ & & & 1 & 1_3\\ \cline{2-6} & & & 2 & 0 & 2_3\\ \end{array} $$So we have $202_3-1200_3=-(1200_3-202_3)$. $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 1 & 2 & 0 & 0_3\\ &-& & 2 & 0 & 2_3\\ \cline{2-6} & & & 2 & 2 & 1_3\\ \end{array} $$Our answer is $\boxed{-221_3}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 121"
and h1 : "b = 2122"
and h2 : "c = 1200"
and h3 : "d = 2111"
shows  "a + b - c - d = -221"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Calculate the result of 121 plus 2122 minus 1200 minus 2111. The final answer is -221.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "a = int_of (3, 121)"
and h1 : "b = int_of (3, 2122)"
and h2 : "c = int_of (3, 1200)"
and h3 : "d = int_of (3, 2111)"
shows  "int_of (3, a + b - c - d) = -221"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $121_3+2122_3-1200_3-2111_3$. Express your answer in base 3. The final Answer is -221_3
 ### Proof
 It doesn't matter the order in which we add and subtract values, but we'll start with $2122_3-2111_3$ since the values are close. $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 2& 1 & 2 & 2_3\\ &- & 2 & 1 & 1 & 1_3\\ \cline{2-6} & & & & 1 & 1_3\\ \end{array} $$Now we're left with  $121_3-1200_3+11_3$.
 We add $121_3+11_3$. $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & & 1 & 2 & 1_3\\ &+ & & & 1 & 1_3\\ \cline{2-6} & & & 2 & 0 & 2_3\\ \end{array} $$So we have $202_3-1200_3=-(1200_3-202_3)$. $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 1 & 2 & 0 & 0_3\\ &-& & 2 & 0 & 2_3\\ \cline{2-6} & & & 2 & 2 & 1_3\\ \end{array} $$Our answer is $\boxed{-221_3}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "a = int_of (3, 121)"
and h1 : "b = int_of (3, 2122)"
and h2 : "c = int_of (3, 1200)"
and h3 : "d = int_of (3, 2111)"
shows  "int_of (3, a + b - c - d) = -221"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given four integers a, b, c, and d such that a is equal to the integer representation of the pair (3, 121), b is equal to the integer representation of the pair (3, 2122), c is equal to the integer representation of the pair (3, 1200), and d is equal to the integer representation of the pair (3, 2111), calculate the integer representation of the pair (3, a + b - c - d). The final answer is -221.

shows  "x + y - z - w = -221"

 *)

assumes h0 : "a = 121"
and h1 : "b = 2122"

and h3 : "d = 2111"
and h4 : "a + b - c - d = -221"

theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "a = 121"

and h2 : "c = 1200"

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y z w :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 44"
and h1 : "y = 80"
and h2 : "z = 54"
and h3 : "w = 70"
shows  "x + y - z - w = -29" (* -221 in base 3 *)
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $121_3+2122_3-1200_3-2111_3$. Express your answer in base 3. The final Answer is -221_3
 ### Proof
 It doesn't matter the order in which we add and subtract values, but we'll start with $2122_3-2111_3$ since the values are close. $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 2& 1 & 2 & 2_3\\ &- & 2 & 1 & 1 & 1_3\\ \cline{2-6} & & & & 1 & 1_3\\ \end{array} $$Now we're left with  $121_3-1200_3+11_3$.
 We add $121_3+11_3$. $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & & 1 & 2 & 1_3\\ &+ & & & 1 & 1_3\\ \cline{2-6} & & & 2 & 0 & 2_3\\ \end{array} $$So we have $202_3-1200_3=-(1200_3-202_3)$. $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 1 & 2 & 0 & 0_3\\ &-& & 2 & 0 & 2_3\\ \cline{2-6} & & & 2 & 2 & 1_3\\ \end{array} $$Our answer is $\boxed{-221_3}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x y z w :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 44"
and h1 : "y = 80"
and h2 : "z = 54"
and h3 : "w = 70"
shows  "x + y - z - w = -29" (* -221 in base 3 *)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given that $x = 44$, $y = 80$, $z = 54$, and $w = 70$, calculate the result of $x + y - z - w$. The final answer is $-29$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "a = int_of_string "
and h1 : " base: 3"
and h2 : "b = int_of_string "
and h3 : " base: 3"
and h4 : "c = int_of_string "
and h5 : " base: 3"
and h6 : "d = int_of_string "
and h7 : " base: 3"
shows  "a + b - c - d = int_of_string "-221" base: 3"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $121_3+2122_3-1200_3-2111_3$. Express your answer in base 3. The final Answer is -221_3
 ### Proof
 It doesn't matter the order in which we add and subtract values, but we'll start with $2122_3-2111_3$ since the values are close. $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 2& 1 & 2 & 2_3\\ &- & 2 & 1 & 1 & 1_3\\ \cline{2-6} & & & & 1 & 1_3\\ \end{array} $$Now we're left with  $121_3-1200_3+11_3$.
 We add $121_3+11_3$. $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & & 1 & 2 & 1_3\\ &+ & & & 1 & 1_3\\ \cline{2-6} & & & 2 & 0 & 2_3\\ \end{array} $$So we have $202_3-1200_3=-(1200_3-202_3)$. $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 1 & 2 & 0 & 0_3\\ &-& & 2 & 0 & 2_3\\ \cline{2-6} & & & 2 & 2 & 1_3\\ \end{array} $$Our answer is $\boxed{-221_3}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "a = int_of_string "
and h1 : " base: 3"
and h2 : "b = int_of_string "
and h3 : " base: 3"
and h4 : "c = int_of_string "
and h5 : " base: 3"
and h6 : "d = int_of_string "
and h7 : " base: 3"
shows  "a + b - c - d = int_of_string "-221" base: 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given four integers a, b, c, d represented in base 3. If the result of the operation a + b - c - d equals to -221 (also represented in base 3), what are the values of a, b, c, d?

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n1 n2 n3 n4 :: int
assumes h0 : "n1 = 121"
and h1 : "n2 = 2122"
and h2 : "n3 = 1200"
and h3 : "n4 = 2111"
and h4 : "n1 + n2 - n3 - n4 = -221"
shows  "(n1 + n2 - n3 - n4) div 3 = -221 div 3"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $121_3+2122_3-1200_3-2111_3$. Express your answer in base 3. The final Answer is -221_3
 ### Proof
 It doesn't matter the order in which we add and subtract values, but we'll start with $2122_3-2111_3$ since the values are close. $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 2& 1 & 2 & 2_3\\ &- & 2 & 1 & 1 & 1_3\\ \cline{2-6} & & & & 1 & 1_3\\ \end{array} $$Now we're left with  $121_3-1200_3+11_3$.
 We add $121_3+11_3$. $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & & 1 & 2 & 1_3\\ &+ & & & 1 & 1_3\\ \cline{2-6} & & & 2 & 0 & 2_3\\ \end{array} $$So we have $202_3-1200_3=-(1200_3-202_3)$. $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 1 & 2 & 0 & 0_3\\ &-& & 2 & 0 & 2_3\\ \cline{2-6} & & & 2 & 2 & 1_3\\ \end{array} $$Our answer is $\boxed{-221_3}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n1 n2 n3 n4 :: int
assumes h0 : "n1 = 121"
and h1 : "n2 = 2122"
and h2 : "n3 = 1200"
and h3 : "n4 = 2111"
and h4 : "n1 + n2 - n3 - n4 = -221"
shows  "(n1 + n2 - n3 - n4) div 3 = -221 div 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: If four numbers are given as 121, 2122, 1200, and 2111, what is the result of adding the first two numbers, subtracting the next two, and then dividing the result by 3? The final answer is the result of -221 divided by 3.

 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "a = int_of_string ('121_3)"
and h1 : "b = int_of_string ('2122_3)"
and h2 : "c = int_of_string ('1200_3)"
and h3 : "d = int_of_string ('2111_3)"
shows  "(a + b - c - d) = int_of_string ('-221_3)"

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y z w. a = nat_of_base 3 "
and h1 : " + nat_of_base 3 "
and h2 : " - nat_of_base 3 "
and h3 : " - nat_of_base 3 "
and h4 : ""
shows  "a = nat_of_base 3 "-221""
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 ### Proof
 It doesn't matter the order in which we add and subtract values, but we'll start with $2122_3-2111_3$ since the values are close. $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 2& 1 & 2 & 2_3\\ &- & 2 & 1 & 1 & 1_3\\ \cline{2-6} & & & & 1 & 1_3\\ \end{array} $$Now we're left with  $121_3-1200_3+11_3$.

 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y z w. a = nat_of_base 3 "
and h1 : " + nat_of_base 3 "
and h2 : " - nat_of_base 3 "
and h3 : " - nat_of_base 3 "
and h4 : ""
shows  "a = nat_of_base 3 "-221""

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: The problem seems to be incomplete and inconsistent. The assumptions do not mention variables x, y, z, w. Also, the statement after assumptions h1, h2, and h3 are not completed. Thus, it's impossible to translate this into a natural language problem.
